html:
Design is flattening. So, how will you fight for your users?

How systems convening can help us keep user-centred design alive — even in the shadows.

The design landscape once felt like a vibrant city: research highways flowed with insights, and user-centred design shaped lively neighbourhoods. Now, under the bulldozers of speed and scale, these vibrant communities risk being flattened into a uniform super estate.

Times are scary, and many wonder, “Do I keep trying, or do I just move on to something else?”

Meanwhile, I’m thinking:

  • Who will fight for the users?
  • Who will be allowed to uncover the truth?
  • When will we turn knowledge into meaningful action?

If the new design landscape permits us from doing any of the above, will we have no choice but to practice “real” UX under the radar?

Without making it sound all doom and gloom, a lot of hope lies in what many UX professionals excel at: systems convening.

What is systems convening? And how did I function as one, even without realising it? I’ll let you in on some secrets…

Systems conveners and UX by stealth
